elements.content: <ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="simple-para0030" view="all">Three unusual 3D 4d–4f coordination polymer, [AgLn(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ox)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O [Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Eu (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>); Dy (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>); Ho (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)] [nic<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nicotinate; ox<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>oxalate] were successfully synthesized. All three structures exhibit same 3D open heterometallic coordination frameworks that are constructed from rare zigzag lanthanide-ox-silver chains and nic linkers.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Three unusual 3D 4d-4f coordination polymer, [AgLn(nic)2(ox)]⋅2H2O [Ln=Eu (1); Dy (2); Ho (3)] [nic=nicotinate; ox=oxalate] were successfully synthesized. All three structures exhibit same 3D open heterometallic coordination frameworks that are constructed from rare zigzag lanthanide-ox-silver chains and nic linkers.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="simple-para0035" view="all">By control of mixed organic ligands with different geometries, three unusual 4d–4f heterometallic coordination polymers, [AgLn(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ox)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O [Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Eu (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>); Dy (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>); Ho (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)] [nic<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nicotinate; ox<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>oxalate] have been synthesized under hydrothermal reaction. Three structures represent 3D open heterometallic coordination frameworks that are constructed from rare zigzag lanthanide-ox-silver chains and nic linkers. Furthermore, the luminescent property of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was discussed.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

By control of mixed organic ligands with different geometries, three unusual 4d-4f heterometallic coordination polymers, [AgLn(nic)2(ox)]⋅2H2O [Ln=Eu (1); Dy (2); Ho (3)] [nic=nicotinate; ox=oxalate] have been synthesized under hydrothermal reaction. Three structures represent 3D open heterometallic coordination frameworks that are constructed from rare zigzag lanthanide-ox-silver chains and nic linkers. Furthermore, the luminescent property of complex 1 was discussed.

elements.content: <ce:para id="para0005" view="all">Lanthanide–transition metal heterometallic complexes with bridging multifunctional organic ligands are of increasing interest not only stems from their versatile applications in magnetism, their conductivity, photoluminescence, bimetallic catalysis but also from their impressive topological structures and motifs . A number of lanthanide-transition metal heterometallic complexes have been successfully obtained from spontaneous assembly of mixed metal ions and ligands containing mixed-donor atoms, such as pyridinecarboxylate, carbonyl, CN group, amino acids and so on . In addition, open heterometallic coordination frameworks with porosity from which the guest species can be removed have been shown to be very promising materials. The construction of open heterometallic coordination frameworks, however, is still a formidable task due to the variable and versatile coordination numbers of the lanthanide ions, their low stereochemical preference and also because of competitive reactions between lanthanide and transition metals coordinated to the same organic ligands . Nevertheless, fortunately, according to the hard-soft acid base theory, lanthanide and transition metal ions have different affinities for the N- and O-donors, which thus provides the impetus to construct novel multi-dimensional heterometallic coordination frameworks with intriguing structural motifs and useful physical–chemical properties .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Lanthanide-transition metal heterometallic complexes with bridging multifunctional organic ligands are of increasing interest not only stems from their versatile applications in magnetism, their conductivity, photoluminescence, bimetallic catalysis but also from their impressive topological structures and motifs . A number of lanthanide-transition metal heterometallic complexes have been successfully obtained from spontaneous assembly of mixed metal ions and ligands containing mixed-donor atoms, such as pyridinecarboxylate, carbonyl, CN group, amino acids and so on . In addition, open heterometallic coordination frameworks with porosity from which the guest species can be removed have been shown to be very promising materials. The construction of open heterometallic coordination frameworks, however, is still a formidable task due to the variable and versatile coordination numbers of the lanthanide ions, their low stereochemical preference and also because of competitive reactions between lanthanide and transition metals coordinated to the same organic ligands . Nevertheless, fortunately, according to the hard-soft acid base theory, lanthanide and transition metal ions have different affinities for the N- and O-donors, which thus provides the impetus to construct novel multi-dimensional heterometallic coordination frameworks with intriguing structural motifs and useful physical-chemical properties .

elements.content: <ce:para id="para0010" view="all">When using bifunctional ligands with both O-donor of carboxylate group and N-donor function (e.g. pyridine carboxylic acid), the 4f ions (lanthanide ions) act as hard acid, thus they prefer oxygen to nitrogen donors and possess high coordination numbers and variable coordination geometries to form e.g. lanthanide carboxylate subunits, while soft transition metal ions, such as Ag(I) or Cu(I) ions bind more easily to ligands with N-donor atoms to link the lanthanide carboxylate subunits . So far, much research work of 3d–4f heterometallic coordination polymers have been reported, but the 4d–4f coordination frameworks have received less attention .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: When using bifunctional ligands with both O-donor of carboxylate group and N-donor function (e.g. pyridine carboxylic acid), the 4f ions (lanthanide ions) act as hard acid, thus they prefer oxygen to nitrogen donors and possess high coordination numbers and variable coordination geometries to form e.g. lanthanide carboxylate subunits, while soft transition metal ions, such as Ag(I) or Cu(I) ions bind more easily to ligands with N-donor atoms to link the lanthanide carboxylate subunits . So far, much research work of 3d-4f heterometallic coordination polymers have been reported, but the 4d-4f coordination frameworks have received less attention .

elements.content: <ce:para id="para0015" view="all">Nicotinic acid as a bifunctional bridging ligand possesses of oxygen and nitrogen donors, which can be chose to as a potential linker between the lanthanide centers and the Ag centers. The oxalate dianion is also an excellent bridging ligand for linking the lanthanide metal centers. On the basis of above-mentioned considerations, we obtained three new 4d–4f coordination polymers, namely [AgLn(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ox)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O [Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Eu (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>); Dy (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>); Ho (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>);] [nic<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nicotinate; ox<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>oxalate] . These complexes have been characterized by IR spectroscopy, elemental analysis, single crystal diffraction, and by photoluminescence. In the IR spectra of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the features at about 1560–1608<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> are attributed to the asymmetric stretching vibrations for carboxylate groups and at about 1404<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for symmetric stretching vibrations for carboxylate groups. Broad bands in the region of 3300–3500<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> can be ascribed to the vibration of water molecules in these compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Nicotinic acid as a bifunctional bridging ligand possesses of oxygen and nitrogen donors, which can be chose to as a potential linker between the lanthanide centers and the Ag centers. The oxalate dianion is also an excellent bridging ligand for linking the lanthanide metal centers. On the basis of above-mentioned considerations, we obtained three new 4d-4f coordination polymers, namely [AgLn(nic)2(ox)]⋅2H2O [Ln=Eu (1); Dy (2); Ho (3);] [nic=nicotinate; ox=oxalate] . These complexes have been characterized by IR spectroscopy, elemental analysis, single crystal diffraction, and by photoluminescence. In the IR spectra of compounds 1-3, the features at about 1560-1608cm-1 are attributed to the asymmetric stretching vibrations for carboxylate groups and at about 1404cm-1 for symmetric stretching vibrations for carboxylate groups. Broad bands in the region of 3300-3500cm-1 can be ascribed to the vibration of water molecules in these compounds.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0020" view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction studies  revealed that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are of isostructural architecture, and the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is representatively described in detail here. It exhibits 3D open heterometallic coordination framework that is constructed from rare zigzag lanthanide-ox-silver chains and nic linkers, crystallizing in monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>. There exist one Eu(III) ion, one Ag(I) ion, two halves of oxalate ligand, two crystallographically unique nic ligands, and two lattice water molecules (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>). Each Eu(III) ion is eight-coordinated by four O-donors of two different oxalate ligands, and four O-donors from different four nic ligands. The Eu center can be described as having a bicapped trigonal prism coordination geometry with Eu–O bond distances ranging from 2.136(3) to 2.494(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which in agreement to what have been observed in other Ln(nic) complexes . The Ag(I) ion is a ‘T-shaped’ configuration and defined by two nitrogen atoms from two different nic anions and one oxygen atom from one ox anion. The two Ag–N bond distances are 2.166(4) and 2.173(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, one Ag–O bond distance is 2.508(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the N–Ag–N angle is 153.49°, which are similar to those of other Ag(I) structures with ‘T-shaped’ configuration . In the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the two nic ligands only adopt a bridging coordination mode, as depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>a, the nitrogen atom coordinates to one Ag center and the carboxylate group connects two Eu centers through a bismonodentate coordination. The oxalate ligands exhibit two types of coordination modes: one only acts in a μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> bridging and chelating mode to link two Eu(III) ions (b), the other acts in a μ<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> bridging and chelating way to link two Eu(III) ions and two Ag(I) ions (c).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Single crystal X-ray diffraction studies  revealed that 1, 2 and 3 are of isostructural architecture, and the structure of 1 is representatively described in detail here. It exhibits 3D open heterometallic coordination framework that is constructed from rare zigzag lanthanide-ox-silver chains and nic linkers, crystallizing in monoclinic space group P21/c. There exist one Eu(III) ion, one Ag(I) ion, two halves of oxalate ligand, two crystallographically unique nic ligands, and two lattice water molecules ( ). Each Eu(III) ion is eight-coordinated by four O-donors of two different oxalate ligands, and four O-donors from different four nic ligands. The Eu center can be described as having a bicapped trigonal prism coordination geometry with Eu-O bond distances ranging from 2.136(3) to 2.494(3)Å, which in agreement to what have been observed in other Ln(nic) complexes . The Ag(I) ion is a ‘T-shaped' configuration and defined by two nitrogen atoms from two different nic anions and one oxygen atom from one ox anion. The two Ag-N bond distances are 2.166(4) and 2.173(4)Å, one Ag-O bond distance is 2.508(3)Å, and the N-Ag-N angle is 153.49°, which are similar to those of other Ag(I) structures with ‘T-shaped' configuration . In the structure of 1, the two nic ligands only adopt a bridging coordination mode, as depicted in  a, the nitrogen atom coordinates to one Ag center and the carboxylate group connects two Eu centers through a bismonodentate coordination. The oxalate ligands exhibit two types of coordination modes: one only acts in a μ4 bridging and chelating mode to link two Eu(III) ions (b), the other acts in a μ6 bridging and chelating way to link two Eu(III) ions and two Ag(I) ions (c).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0025" view="all">In the polymeric structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the oxalate ligands with above-mentioned two types of coordination modes in turn link europium and silver centers to give rise to one zigzag lanthanide-ox-silver chain (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>a), in which the Eu⋯Ag separation of the dinuclear EuAg cluster is 4.701<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. These chains are further interconnected by nic ligands to form an unusual coordination framework with one-dimensional channels running along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis of unit cell (b). 1D zigzag water chains occupy these channels and also extend in the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis direction (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>a). In the 3D coordination framework, europium centers and silver centers are linked by carboxylate groups of nic and ox ligands to form 2D layer in the ac plane (b). The adjacent distances of Eu⋯Eu are 6.309 and 4.224<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and opposite Ag⋯Ag separation is 7.401<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Therefore, the 3D coordination framework can also be regarded as the assembly of 2D heterometallic Ln–Ag layers and nic ligands. The arrangement is analogous to that of the structure [NdCu(inic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ox)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, (inic<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>isonicotinate) , but the structural motif is different. To our knowledge, these isostructural compounds are the first 3D 4d–4f heterometallic coordination frameworks based on lanthanide-ox-silver chains and nic ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the polymeric structure of 1, the oxalate ligands with above-mentioned two types of coordination modes in turn link europium and silver centers to give rise to one zigzag lanthanide-ox-silver chain ( a), in which the Eu⋯Ag separation of the dinuclear EuAg cluster is 4.701Å. These chains are further interconnected by nic ligands to form an unusual coordination framework with one-dimensional channels running along the c-axis of unit cell (b). 1D zigzag water chains occupy these channels and also extend in the c-axis direction ( a). In the 3D coordination framework, europium centers and silver centers are linked by carboxylate groups of nic and ox ligands to form 2D layer in the ac plane (b). The adjacent distances of Eu⋯Eu are 6.309 and 4.224Å, and opposite Ag⋯Ag separation is 7.401Å. Therefore, the 3D coordination framework can also be regarded as the assembly of 2D heterometallic Ln-Ag layers and nic ligands. The arrangement is analogous to that of the structure [NdCu(inic)2(ox)]⋅H2O, (inic=isonicotinate) , but the structural motif is different. To our knowledge, these isostructural compounds are the first 3D 4d-4f heterometallic coordination frameworks based on lanthanide-ox-silver chains and nic ligands.

elements.clean_text: The luminescent property of 1 was investigated in the solid state. The emission spectrum of the complex 1 ( ) at the excited wavelength of 395nm exhibit the characteristic emission of Eu(III) ion, which can be attributed to 5D0 → 7F n  (n =0→4) transitions, i.e., 579nm (5D0 → 7F0), 592nm (5D0 → 7F1), 612, 616, 619 and 620nm (5D0 → 7F2), 650nm (5D0 → 7F3), 699nm (5D0 → 7F4), indicating a moderately efficient of ligand-to-metal (europium) energy transfer (LMCT) . The symmetry-forbidden weak emission peak 5D0  →  7F0 at 579nm indicates that the Eu(III) ions are located on a low symmetry site . The emission peak 5D0 → 7F1 is a magnetic dipole transition, and its intensity should vary with the crystal field strength acting on the Eu(III) ions. The strongest emission peak 5D0 → 7F2 transition is an electric dipole transition and is extremely sensitive to chemical bonds in the vicinity of Eu(III) ion. In the spectrum, the strongest emission peak in the 5D0 → 7F2 transition region was split into four levels at 612, 616, 619 and 620nm, which can be ascribed to the splitting of energy levels. Because the presence of Eu(III) ion site with low symmetry the emission peak in the 5D0  →  7F2 transition can be split. The intensity ratio I(5D0 → 7F2)/I(5D0 → 7F1) is equal to ca. 7.48, which also suggests that the Eu(III) ions in 1 have a non-centrosymmetric coordination environment. This is also consistent with the result of the single crystal X-ray analysis .

elements.content: <ce:para id="para0035" view="all">In summary, we have successfully constructed three novel isostructural heterometallic coordination polymers with 1D channels based on Ln–ox–Ag chains and nic ligands. This synthetic route may be applicable to prepare other novel high-dimensional lanthanide–transition metal coordination polymers with interesting structural, topologies and functional properties.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have successfully constructed three novel isostructural heterometallic coordination polymers with 1D channels based on Ln-ox-Ag chains and nic ligands. This synthetic route may be applicable to prepare other novel high-dimensional lanthanide-transition metal coordination polymers with interesting structural, topologies and functional properties.

   Crystal Strucuters  Crystallographic data.     

The synthesis of complexes is as follows: A mixture of AgNO3 (0.168g, 1mmol), Ln(NO3)3 ⋅6H2O [0.446g, 1mmol for 1; 0.456g, 1mmol for 2; 0.458g, 1mmol for 3], oxalic acid (0.900g, 1mmol), nic (0.123g, 1mmol), and H2O (10ml) was stirred for 30min in air and then sealed in a 23mL Teflon reactor and kept under autogenous pressure at 150°C for 4days. The mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10°Ch-1, and yellow blocky crystals were obtained in a yield of 50% based on Eu for 1 [45% based on Dy for 2; 42% based on Ho for 3]. 1: C14H12AgEuN2O10 (628.09): calcd. C, 26.77, H, 1.92, N, 4.46; found C, 26.70, H, 1.95, N, 4.41. IR (KBr): 3417, 1608(vs), 1562(vs), 1406(m), 1325(m), 1118(w), 796(m), 759(w), 702cm-1. 2: C14H12AgDyN2O10 (638.63): calcd. cln_elements.clean_text:
The luminescent property of 1 was investigated in the solid state. The emission spectrum of the complex 1 ( ) at the excited wavelength of 395nm exhibit the characteristic emission of Eu(III) ion, which can be attributed to 5D0 → 7F n  (n =0→4) transitions, i.e., 579nm (5D0 → 7F0), 592nm (5D0 → 7F1), 612, 616, 619 and 620nm (5D0 → 7F2), 650nm (5D0 → 7F3), 699nm (5D0 → 7F4), indicating a moderately efficient of ligand-to-metal (europium) energy transfer (LMCT) . The symmetry-forbidden weak emission peak 5D0  →  7F0 at 579nm indicates that the Eu(III) ions are located on a low symmetry site . The emission peak 5D0 → 7F1 is a magnetic dipole transition, and its intensity should vary with the crystal field strength acting on the Eu(III) ions. The strongest emission peak 5D0 → 7F2 transition is an electric dipole transition and is extremely sensitive to chemical bonds in the vicinity of Eu(III) ion. In the spectrum, the strongest emission peak in the 5D0 → 7F2 transition region was split into four levels at 612, 616, 619 and 620nm, which can be ascribed to the splitting of energy levels. Because the presence of Eu(III) ion site with low symmetry the emission peak in the 5D0  →  7F2 transition can be split. The intensity ratio I(5D0 → 7F2)/I(5D0 → 7F1) is equal to ca. 7.48, which also suggests that the Eu(III) ions in 1 have a non-centrosymmetric coordination environment. This is also consistent with the result of the single crystal X-ray analysis .

Crystallographic data for complex 1: monoclinic P21/c, with a =9.7109(2), b =22.3358(5), c =9.1581(2)Å, β =117.485(1)°, V =1762.20(7)Å3, Z =4, D C =2.367, F(000)=1200, GOF=1.021, R 1 (I >2σ(I))=0.0241 and wR 2 (all data)=0.0573. 2: monoclinic P21/c, with a =9.67980(10), b =22.2733(3), c =9.1262(1)Å, β =117.872(1)°, V =1739.36(4)Å3, Z =4, D C =2.439, F(000)=1212, GOF=1.115, R 1 (I >2σ(I))=0.0259 and wR 2 (all data)=0.0590. 3: monoclinic P21/c, with a =9.6639(1), b =22.2590(3), c =9.1137(1)Å, β=117.960(1)°, V =1731.60(4)Å3, Z =4, D C =2.459, F(000)=1216, GOF=1.041, R 1 (I >2σ(I))=0.0209 and wR 2 (all data)=0.0460.
